posts.name: Adam Fleming
posts.cooked:
In the case of 3596, our founding mentors worked at Bucyrus/Caterpillar Global Mining that worked on dragline excavators and electric rope shovels. Many of our designs have utilized a rope/cable and spool/drum mechanism to raise, extend, or pull back on something. Even with these mentors gone, for a few years, I still find myself creating examples and designs using this rope and spool design.

What design staples does your team have that are influenced by your mentors jobs?

So, Yes.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: We have a couple mentors in automation, and it seems like every year we have to have a meeting to rename the subsystems that got named after some Fanuc related acronyms. For example EOAT, lip roller, J1, J2, J3 etc. I find that FRC effects my profession design work as much if not more that my job affects robots.

posts.name: ToddF
posts.cooked:
Patrick3357:

I find that FRC effects my profession design work as much if not more that my job affects robots.

I’m with you on this one.  I designed the inflation system on the LOFTID spacecraft that was launched in November .  The structural backbone of that system was a 1x2x1/8" wall tube with end joints like we use to join our frame rails in our West Coast Drive chassis.

But, going the other way, working in aerospace has taught me the value of having a global coordinate system and using that for assembling the major subsystems of the robot in CAD, rather than using assembly references to things that might go away later.  So, all our major CAD subsystems begin with a skeleton part with datum planes for water line, butt line, and fuselage station (labeled WL0, BL0, FS0).  WL0 is the floor.  FS0 is the fore/aft centerline.  BL0 is the side to side centerline.  The skeleton gets updated each year with datums for things like starting configuration constraints and extension limits.  The first part of each of the robot subsystems is positioned in space relative to those 3 datum planes.  Then the subsystems are assembled by matching robot coordinate systems.  From then on, anyone can work on any subsystem CAD concurrently with any other without worrying that the top level model will blow up by messing up assembly references.

I learned this approach at work, and have had it validated over many years of rapid, concurrent design on the robotics team.  So when I was setting up the master CAD model for the LOFTID spacecraft, I used that approach there, too.  With the interfaces defined in the skeleton, team members can work concurrently in each of the major subassemblies without needing to know what’s happening in the other major assemblies.  You just need one person to keep an eye on the top level assembly to make sure all the subassemblies are playing well together.

posts.cooked: Our lead mentor, @Strategic , used to weld sets for plays! He uses his experience to train team members and this allows us to be one of the few FNC teams that are able to weld. While we have learned that sometimes welding is not the best for modularity, it is certainly always a great option to have in your back pocket.

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: Whenever I hear the term “boomstick” I get a picture of Bruce Campbell with a chainsaw for a hand in my head. Can’t imagine why…

posts.name: Brian Wagg
posts.cooked:
Patrick3357:

I find that FRC effects my profession design work as much if not more that my job affects robots.

I have my current job (CNC programmer and Draftsperson) because of the influences in design from a mentor in high school. We had access to a lot of sheet metal equipment through his workplace, and because of this, we learned to design a lot of our robot with sheet metal/forming. I’ve carried this design “style” on with me to my current team.

Later in college I was given the opportunity to apply for my current job because my prof had seen the sheet metal work I’d done in FRC , and knew I was the most proficient student he had to recommend (sheet metal design wasn’t ever touched on/offered through the courses my college ran).

posts.name: Peter Matteson
posts.cooked:
This is why team 177 always has fuel cell powered robots.

But seriously the weight we lighten and  how we design supports links and brackets is due to the fact many of the mentors work or have worked in aerospace so we design things from that mindset so you will see a design language in our robots that is a carry over from working on aircraft.

Also some of our earliest mentors built their own aircraft which influenced our early designs with sheet metal monocoque construction and solid riveting.

After 20 years in the Navy, I keep hoping for that water game to come around so I can leverage my experience.  For now, it is prinicples learned in the nuclear power world, as well as 15 years of building Jeeps, SxSs, pyrotechnics, etc.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: “Bruce Campbell Movies” would be a great running theme for robot names. Just sayin.

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: It does present a host of possibilities, doesn’t it? I’d totally name a robot “Army of Darkness” and “Sky High” is a pretty obvious name for a robot too. Expand the theme to Bruce’s roles and you could really go to town with it.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
Oddly, I really can’t think of any.  This being Iowa, many of our mentors work in or adjacent to the Ag Industry, but so far no overwhelming urge to paint things John Deere green or whatever.

I guess if we show up with an intake that looks like a combine corn head, you’ll know it happened.

posts.name: Peter Matteson
posts.cooked: I mean “The Adventures of Brisco County Jr” is a great name for a robot, but so is “Bubba Ho-Tep”.
